main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: So to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to connect with people from other teams, we try to assign everyone to a more social team that we call groups that consist of people who joined the company at around the same time as you.
Oh, that sounds really cool. How big are these groups?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: The size varies, but I think the smallest group has around 14 or 15 members? We have 9 teams at the moment, so it is likely that one of your groupmates is also your teammate.
Is every team represented in every group?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: We try to aim for this, but of course that is not always possible. I'd say that most groups do have a majority of the teams represented in them however. By grouping you with colleagues that have similar amounts of experience at our company, we try to really give the group a feeling of cohesion and the feeling that you are growing as a group with each other and the company.
Yeah, that is also what really piqued my interest, it sounds like a very cool concept.
Is it also common then that these groups go to social activities together outside of work time?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Yes, that happens every now and then, either with the whole group or a smaller portion of the group. The company also offers a bimonthly budget for the group to do something together.
Oh, so the company is really trying to encourage people from different teams to connect with eachother?

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: Yes, we think that this enables more creativity but also keeps everyone from different teams informed about what other teams are doing.
Oh right, because more often than not, you do not really know what other teams are doing since you are only working with your own team.

main.speaker: Mr. Jefferson
main.text: And with this group structure, we hope that everyone in the company knows at least a little bit about what other people outside of their own team are working on.
